skill.name: no-hardcoding
skill.description: Forbid hardcoded values in code. Use this when reviewing code, writing new features, or when magic numbers/strings are detected. Enforces constants, env variables, and config files.

skill.author: Doyajin174

security_audit.summary: Pure markdown documentation skill containing coding guidelines. No executable code, no file system access beyond its own content, no network calls, and no external command execution. The skill provides educational examples and best practices for avoiding hardcoded values in code.

content.value_statement: Hardcoded values make code difficult to maintain and create security risks. This skill enforces the use of constants, environment variables, and configuration files to improve code quality and security.
actual_capabilities: Detect magic numbers and magic strings in code
Identify hardcoded URLs and file paths
Flag hardcoded credentials and API keys
Recommend constants and environment variables as alternatives
Provide file organization patterns for constants
limitations: Does not automatically refactor code - only provides guidance
Does not access external APIs or services
Does not modify files without explicit user request
Relies on AI to apply recommendations during code review

use_cases.title: Code review enforcement
use_cases.description: Apply consistent standards when reviewing pull requests to catch hardcoded values before merge.

use_cases.title: API configuration
use_cases.description: Ensure API endpoints, timeouts, and credentials use environment variables instead of hardcoded strings.

use_cases.title: Credential safety
use_cases.description: Prevent accidental hardcoding of API keys, passwords, and database credentials in source code.

prompt_templates.title: Quick check
prompt_templates.prompt: Review this code for hardcoded values. Report any magic numbers, magic strings, hardcoded URLs, or credentials that should be replaced with constants or environment variables.

prompt_templates.title: Full review
prompt_templates.prompt: Perform a complete review of this codebase for hardcoding violations. List all findings by category: magic numbers, magic strings, URLs, credentials, and timeouts. Suggest specific constants or environment variables for each violation.

prompt_templates.title: Refactor plan
prompt_templates.prompt: Identify all hardcoded values in this code. Create a refactoring plan that extracts each value into appropriate constants or environment variables with suggested names.

prompt_templates.title: Policy enforcement
prompt_templates.prompt: Audit this code against our no-hardcoding policy. Verify no credentials, API keys, or sensitive values are hardcoded. Report any violations with severity level and recommended fix.

output_examples.input: Review this function for hardcoding: const timeout = 5000; const apiUrl = 'https://api.example.com'; const apiKey = 'sk-test123';
output: ‚ö†Ô∏è Hardcoded timeout value (5000ms) - Extract to TIMEOUT_MS constant
‚ö†Ô∏è Hardcoded API URL - Use environment variable like process.env.API_URL
üö® CRITICAL: Hardcoded API key detected - Never hardcode credentials. Use environment variable or secrets manager.

best_practices: Extract magic numbers and strings into named constants before they are used in multiple places
Store all credentials, API keys, and secrets in environment variables or a secrets manager
Use configuration files with environment-specific overrides for deployment values
anti_patterns: Using literal numbers like 3000 instead of named constants like DEBOUNCE_MS
Hardcoding API endpoints directly in fetch calls instead of using environment variables
Storing passwords, API keys, or tokens directly in source code

faq.question: Which programming languages does this skill support?
faq.answer: This skill works with any programming language. Examples use TypeScript but the principles apply to Python, Java, Go, and others.

faq.question: What values should be environment variables?
faq.answer: Credentials, API keys, database URLs, service endpoints, feature flags, and any value that changes between environments.

faq.question: How does this integrate with my codebase?
faq.answer: The skill provides guidelines you apply during code review. It does not modify your code automatically. Use the prompt templates to get recommendations.

faq.question: Is my code data sent anywhere?
faq.answer: No. This skill only processes code you share during the conversation. No data is transmitted to external servers.

faq.question: Why are 0, 1, and -1 allowed as exceptions?
faq.answer: These values have universal semantic meaning in programming. Index -1 for not found, 0 for initial state, and 1 for single items are self-documenting.

faq.question: How is this different from linters?
faq.answer: Linters enforce syntax rules. This skill enforces design and security patterns. Use both together for comprehensive code quality.
